title: CTEs: A tool for simplifying and organizing complex queries.
description: How to use Common Table Expression (CTE) in SQL Server

body.raw:
## Introduction
I had to migrate some data from SQL Server for a new feature in my project. I wrote a script that can handle complex and reusable queries. I also used CTE (Common Table Expression) to make my code easier to read and maintain. In this post, I will show you what CTE is and how to use it.

## CTE in sql server
CTE stands for common table expression, which is a temporary result set that you can use in a statement like `SELECT`, `INSERT`, `UPDATE`, `DELETE`, or `MERGE`. CTEs help you structure your code better and let you perform multi-level aggregations on your data, such as finding the average of a group of counts.

## CTE benefits 
- CTEs improve the readability of code. And readable code makes debugging queries simplier.
- CTEs allow you to use the results multiple times in the query. By saving the results of the subquery, you can use them again in a bigger query.
- CTEs can help you do multi-level aggregations. Use CTEs to save the results of aggregations, which you can then use in the main query.

## CTE syntax
To create a CTE, you use the `WITH` keyword and a variable name that acts as a temporary table that you can use in other parts of your query.

The following shows the common syntax of a CTE in SQL Server:
```sql
WITH cte_name[(column_name [,...])]
AS
    (CTE_definition)
SQL_statement;
```

In this syntax:
- First, given a name the cte `cte_name` that you can use later in a query.
- Next, you can optionally list the columns after the cte_name, separated by commas. The columns must have the same number as the columns in the `CTE_definition`.
- Then, after the cte name or the column list (if you have one), use the `AS` keyword.
- After, define a `SELECT` statement whose result set populates the common table expression.
- Finally, refer to the common table expression in a query (`SQL_statement`) such as `SELECT`, `INSERT`, `UPDATE`, `DELETE`, or `MERGE`.

## CTE example

Let's see some examples of how to use common table expressions.

### Basic CTE example

This query uses a CTE that shows the sales amounts of each sales staff in 2023:

```sql
WITH cte_sales_amounts (staff, sales, year) 
AS (
    SELECT    
        first_name + ' ' + last_name, 
        SUM(quantity * list_price * (1 - discount)),
        YEAR(order_date)
    FROM orders o
      INNER JOIN order_items i ON i.order_id = o.order_id
      INNER JOIN staffs s ON s.staff_id = o.staff_id
    GROUP BY 
        first_name + ' ' + last_name,
        year(order_date)
)

SELECT
    staff, 
    sales
FROM 
    cte_sales_amounts
WHERE
    year = 2023;
```

In this example:
- First, we define a CTE named cte_sales_amounts which returns a result set that consists of three columns `staff`, `sales`, and `year`
- Then, we constructed a query that gets the sum of sales by sales staff and year from the `orders`, `order_items` and `staffs` tables.
- Finally, we referred to the CTE in the main query and selected only the rows whose years are 2023.

### Using a CTE to calculate report averages from counts

This example uses the CTE to calculate the mean number of sales orders in 2023 for all sales staffs.

```sql
WITH cte_sales AS (
    SELECT 
        staff_id, 
        COUNT(*) order_count  
    FROM
        orders
    WHERE 
        YEAR(order_date) = 2023
    GROUP BY
        staff_id

)
SELECT
    AVG(order_count) average_orders_by_staff
FROM 
    cte_sales;
```

### Using more than one CTE in a single query example
The following example gets the product count and sales amount for each product category; we use two CTEs: `cte_category_counts` and `cte_category_sales`. These CTEs are joined by the category_id column in the main query.

```sql
WITH cte_category_counts (
    category_id, 
    category_name, 
    product_count
)
AS (
    SELECT 
        c.category_id, 
        c.category_name, 
        COUNT(p.product_id)
    FROM products p
        INNER JOIN categories c ON c.category_id = p.category_id
    GROUP BY 
        c.category_id, 
        c.category_name
),
cte_category_sales(category_id, sales) AS (
    SELECT    
        p.category_id, 
        SUM(i.quantity * i.list_price * (1 - i.discount))
    FROM order_items i
        INNER JOIN products p ON p.product_id = i.product_id
        INNER JOIN sales.orders o ON o.order_id = i.order_id
    WHERE order_status = 4 -- completed
    GROUP BY 
        p.category_id
) 

SELECT 
    c.category_id, 
    c.category_name, 
    c.product_count, 
    s.sales
FROM
    cte_category_counts c
    INNER JOIN cte_category_sales s 
        ON s.category_id = c.category_id
ORDER BY 
    c.category_name;
```

`,(0,r.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:"This query uses a CTE that shows the sales amounts of each sales staff in 2023:"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"C:\\Users\\Nang\\Documents\\Projects\\nang01t2.github.io\\content\\posts\\en\\blog\\2023\\_mdx_bundler_entry_point-47a90751-8071-47a4-9e8a-ac1c39d40d86.mdx",lineNumber:46,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,r.jsxDEV)(t.pre,{children:(0,r.jsxDEV)(t.code,{className:"language-sql",children:`WITH cte_sales_amounts (staff, sales, year) \r
AS (\r
    SELECT    \r
        first_name + ' ' + last_name, \r
        SUM(quantity * list_price * (1 - discount)),\r
        YEAR(order_date)\r
    FROM orders o\r
      INNER JOIN order_items i ON i.order_id = o.order_id\r
      INNER JOIN staffs s ON s.staff_id = o.staff_id\r
    GROUP BY \r
        first_name + ' ' + last_name,\r
        year(order_date)\r
)\r
\r
SELECT\r
    staff, \r
    sales\r
FROM \r
    cte_sales_amounts\r
WHERE\r
    year = 2023;
`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"C:\\Users\\Nang\\Documents\\Projects\\nang01t2.github.io\\content\\posts\\en\\blog\\2023\\_mdx_bundler_entry_point-47a90751-8071-47a4-9e8a-ac1c39d40d86.mdx",lineNumber:48,columnNumber:1},this)},void 0,!1,{fileName:"C:\\Users\\Nang\\Documents\\Projects\\nang01t2.github.io\\content\\posts\\en\\blog\\2023\\_mdx_bundler_entry_point-47a90751-8071-47a4-9e8a-ac1c39d40d86.mdx",lineNumber:48,columnNumber:1},this),`

`,(0,r.jsxDEV)(t.pre,{children:(0,r.jsxDEV)(t.code,{className:"language-sql",children:`WITH cte_sales AS (\r
    SELECT \r
        staff_id, \r
        COUNT(*) order_count  \r
    FROM\r
        orders\r
    WHERE \r
        YEAR(order_date) = 2023\r
    GROUP BY\r
        staff_id\r
\r
)\r
SELECT\r
    AVG(order_count) average_orders_by_staff\r
FROM \r
    cte_sales;
`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"C:\\Users\\Nang\\Documents\\Projects\\nang01t2.github.io\\content\\posts\\en\\blog\\2023\\_mdx_bundler_entry_point-47a90751-8071-47a4-9e8a-ac1c39d40d86.mdx",lineNumber:81,columnNumber:1},this)},void 0,!1,{fileName:"C:\\Users\\Nang\\Documents\\Projects\\nang01t2.github.io\\content\\posts\\en\\blog\\2023\\_mdx_bundler_entry_point-47a90751-8071-47a4-9e8a-ac1c39d40d86.mdx",lineNumber:81,columnNumber:1},this),`

`,(0,r.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:["The following example gets the product count and sales amount for each product category; we use two CTEs: ",(0,r.jsxDEV)(t.code,{children:"cte_category_counts"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"C:\\Users\\Nang\\Documents\\Projects\\nang01t2.github.io\\content\\posts\\en\\blog\\2023\\_mdx_bundler_entry_point-47a90751-8071-47a4-9e8a-ac1c39d40d86.mdx",lineNumber:101,columnNumber:107},this)," and ",(0,r.jsxDEV)(t.code,{children:"cte_category_sales"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"C:\\Users\\Nang\\Documents\\Projects\\nang01t2.github.io\\content\\posts\\en\\blog\\2023\\_mdx_bundler_entry_point-47a90751-8071-47a4-9e8a-ac1c39d40d86.mdx",lineNumber:101,columnNumber:133},this),". These CTEs are joined by the category_id column in the main query."]},void 0,!0,{fileName:"C:\\Users\\Nang\\Documents\\Projects\\nang01t2.github.io\\content\\posts\\en\\blog\\2023\\_mdx_bundler_entry_point-47a90751-8071-47a4-9e8a-ac1c39d40d86.mdx",lineNumber:101,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,r.jsxDEV)(t.pre,{children:(0,r.jsxDEV)(t.code,{className:"language-sql",children:`WITH cte_category_counts (\r
    category_id, \r
    category_name, \r
    product_count\r
)\r
AS (\r
    SELECT \r
        c.category_id, \r
        c.category_name, \r
        COUNT(p.product_id)\r
    FROM products p\r
        INNER JOIN categories c ON c.category_id = p.category_id\r
    GROUP BY \r
        c.category_id, \r
        c.category_name\r
),\r
cte_category_sales(category_id, sales) AS (\r
    SELECT    \r
        p.category_id, \r
        SUM(i.quantity * i.list_price * (1 - i.discount))\r
    FROM order_items i\r
        INNER JOIN products p ON p.product_id = i.product_id\r
        INNER JOIN sales.orders o ON o.order_id = i.order_id\r
    WHERE order_status = 4 -- completed\r
    GROUP BY \r
        p.category_id\r
) \r
\r
SELECT \r
    c.category_id, \r
    c.category_name, \r
    c.product_count, \r
    s.sales\r
FROM\r
    cte_category_counts c\r
    INNER JOIN cte_category_sales s \r
        ON s.category_id = c.category_id\r
ORDER BY \r
    c.category_name;
`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"C:\\Users\\Nang\\Documents\\Projects\\nang01t2.github.io\\content\\posts\\en\\blog\\2023\\_mdx_bundler_entry_point-47a90751-8071-47a4-9e8a-ac1c39d40d86.mdx",lineNumber:103,columnNumber:1},this)},void 0,!1,{fileName:"C:\\Users\\Nang\\Documents\\Projects\\nang01t2.github.io\\content\\posts\\en\\blog\\2023\\_mdx_bundler_entry_point-47a90751-8071-47a4-9e8a-ac1c39d40d86.mdx",lineNumber:103,columnNumber:1},this)]},void 0,!0,{fileName:"C:\\Users\\Nang\\Documents\\Projects\\nang01t2.github.io\\content\\posts\\en\\blog\\2023\\_mdx_bundler_entry_point-47a90751-8071-47a4-9e8a-ac1c39d40d86.mdx",lineNumber:1,columnNumber:1},this)}function pn(l={}){let{wrapper:t}=l.components||{};return t?(0,r.jsxDEV)(t,Object.assign({},l,{children:(0,r.jsxDEV)(je,l,void 0,!1,{fileName:"C:\\Users\\Nang\\Documents\\Projects\\nang01t2.github.io\\content\\posts\\en\\blog\\2023\\_mdx_bundler_entry_point-47a90751-8071-47a4-9e8a-ac1c39d40d86.mdx"},this)}),void 0,!1,{fileName:"C:\\Users\\Nang\\Documents\\Projects\\nang01t2.github.io\\content\\posts\\en\\blog\\2023\\_mdx_bundler_entry_point-47a90751-8071-47a4-9e8a-ac1c39d40d86.mdx"},this):je(l)}var Nn=pn;return _n(yn);})();

Using more than one CTE in a single query example

## This is a heading ### This is a subheading ### This is a sub-subheading This is a paragraph. You can add emphasis to text by using _asterisks_ or _underscores_. For example, _this text will be italicized_ and _this text will be italicized_. You can also make text **bold** by using **double asterisks** or **double underscore**. For example, **this text will be bold** and **this text will be bold**. You can create lists by using hyphen (-) or asterisks (\*). For example: - Item 1 - Item 2 - Item 3 Or: - Item 1 - Item 2 - Item 3 You can also create ordered lists by using numbers. For example: 1. First item 2. Second item 3. Third item You can add links by using bracket [] and parentheses (). For example: [Google](https://www.google/com) will create a link to Google. You can add images by using an exclamation mark (!), brackets [], and parentheses (). For example: ![Minion](https://octodex.github.com/images/minion.png) "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum." line break with '   ' line break with `
`
--- ## Emphasis **This is bold text** _This is italic text_ ~~Strikethrough~~ ## Blockquotes > Blockquotes can also be nested... > > > ...by using additional greater-than signs right next to each other... > > > > > ...or with spaces between arrows. ## Lists Unordered - Create a list by starting a line with `-` or `*` - Sub-lists are made by indenting 2 spaces: - Marker character change forces new list start: - Ac tristique libero volutpat at * Facilisis in pretium nisl aliquet - Very easy! Ordered 1. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet 2. Consectetur adipiscing elit 3. Integer molestie lorem at massa 4. You can use sequential numbers... 5. ...or keep all the numbers as `1.` Start numbering with offset: 57. foo 1. bar ## Code Inline `code` Block code ``` Sample text here... ``` Syntax highlighting ```js var foo = function (bar) { return bar++; }; console.log(foo(5)); ``` Syntax highlighting with file name, highlight line ```ts:cores.ts {2} export const cn = (classNames: ...any) => { return classNames.filter(Boolean).join(' '); } ``` ## Tables | Option | Description | | ------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | data | path to data files to supply the data that will be passed into templates. | | engine | engine to be used for processing templates. Handlebars is the default. | | ext | extension to be used for dest files. | Right aligned columns | Option | Description | | -----: | ------------------------------------------------------------------------: | | data | path to data files to supply the data that will be passed into templates. | | engine | engine to be used for processing templates. Handlebars is the default. | | ext | extension to be used for dest files. | ## Links [link text](https://nang01t2.github.io/) [**bold link text**](https://nang01t2.github.io/) [`code link text`](https://nang01t2.github.io/) Autoconverted link https://github.com/Nang01T2 ## Images ![Minion](https://octodex.github.com/images/minion.png) HTML `` tag

`,(0,t.jsxDEV)(n.pre,{children:(0,t.jsxDEV)(n.code,{className:"language-ts",children:`import { visit } from "unist-util-visit";\r
\r
export default function remarkAdmonition() {\r
  return (tree) => {\r
    visit(tree, (node) => {\r
      if (\r
        node.type === "textDirective" ||\r
        node.type === "leafDirective" ||\r
        node.type === "containerDirective"\r
      ) {\r
        if (!["info", "warn", "danger"].includes(node.name)) return;\r
        // Store node.name before overwritten with "Alert".\r
        const status = node.name;\r
\r
        const data = node.data || (node.data = {});\r
        const tagName = node.type === "textDirective" ? "span" : "div";\r
\r
        node.type = "mdxJsxFlowElement";\r
        node.name = "Admonition";\r
        node.attributes = [\r
          { type: "mdxJsxAttribute", name: "status", value: status },\r
        ];\r
      }\r
    });\r
  };\r
}

title: How to set up ESLint with Next.js

body.raw:
When your project grows bigger and more developers join the team, it becomes more difficult to manage and maintain. How can you prevent this?

You need to establish some common standards, practices, and tools early in the project to ensure that your code is consistent and clean everywhere.

One of the tools that can help you with this is [ESLint](https://eslint.org/).

https://eslint.org/

## Introduction to ESLint

ESLint is a tool that helps you find and fix problems in your `JavaScript` code. It can check for common errors, such as syntax mistakes, unused variables, or inconsistent formatting. It can also enforce best practices and coding standards, such as avoiding global variables, using strict mode, or following a specific style guide.

## ESLint benefits

Using ESLint can help you improve the quality and maintainability of your code. Some of the benefits are:

- It can catch bugs and errors before they cause problems in your application or affect your users.
- It can make your code more readable and consistent by following a set of rules that you can customize according to your preferences or project requirements.
- It can help you learn from your mistakes and improve your skills as a JavaScript developer.
- It can integrate with your editor, IDE, or build tools to provide real-time feedback and automated fixes.

## Setup ESLint with Nextjs project

Nextjs is a framework that allows you to create fast and user-friendly web applications using React. It comes with some built-in features, such as file-system routing, pre-rendering, code splitting, and API routes. To use ESLint with Nextjs, you need to install some dependencies and create a configuration file.

First, install ESLint and the Nextjs plugin:

```bash
npm install --save-dev eslint eslint-config-next
```

Then, create a file named `.eslintrc.json` in the root of your project and add the following content:

```json title=".eslintrc.json"
{
  "extends": "next"
}
```

This tells ESLint to use the Nextjs plugin, which includes some rules that are specific to Nextjs projects.

You can also add some other plugins or rules to customize your ESLint configuration. For example, you can use the `react-hooks` plugin to enforce the rules of hooks in your React components:

```bash
npm install --save-dev eslint-plugin-react-hooks
```

Then, add it to your `.eslintrc.json` file:

```json title=".eslintrc.json"
{
  "extends": ["next", "plugin:react-hooks/recommended"]
}
```

## Setup more plugins

You can also use some other plugins to enhance your ESLint experience. Here are some examples:

- **eslint-plugin-unused-imports**: This plugin can help you remove unused imports from your code, which can improve your performance and reduce your bundle size.
- **eslint-plugin-import**: This plugin can help you manage your imports better, such as sorting them alphabetically, checking for duplicates, or ensuring consistency.
- **eslint-plugin-tailwindcss**: This plugin can help you use Tailwind CSS in your Nextjs project, such as validating your class names, highlighting errors, or providing autocomplete suggestions.

To install these plugins, run the following command:

```bash
npm install --save-dev eslint-plugin-unused-imports eslint-plugin-import eslint-plugin-tailwindcss
```

Then, add them to your .eslintrc.json file:

```json title=".eslintrc.json"
{
  "extends": [
    "next",
    "plugin:react-hooks/recommended",
    "plugin:unused-imports/recommended",
    "plugin:import/recommended",
    "plugin:tailwindcss/recommended"
  ]
}
```

You may also need to adjust some of the rules or settings according to your needs. For example, you can disable the `no-unused-vars` rule from ESLint core since it is already covered by the `unused-imports` plugin:

```json
{
  "rules": {
    "no-unused-vars": "off"
  }
}
```

## Summary

Thank you for reading this post. I hope it helped you learn more about ESLint, its features, and how to use it in your Nextjs projects.

If you want to see all the rules that you can configure with ESLint, you can visit this [link](https://eslint.org/docs/latest/rules/).

## h2 Heading (Vietnamese Version) ### h3 Heading ### **h3 Bold Heading** #### h4 Heading "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Ut enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exercitation ullamco laboris nisi ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat. Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum." line break with '   ' line break with `

--- ## Emphasis **This is bold text** _This is italic text_ ~~Strikethrough~~ ## Blockquotes > Blockquotes can also be nested... > > > ...by using additional greater-than signs right next to each other... > > > > > ...or with spaces between arrows. ## Lists Unordered - Create a list by starting a line with `-` or `*` - Sub-lists are made by indenting 2 spaces: - Marker character change forces new list start: - Ac tristique libero volutpat at * Facilisis in pretium nisl aliquet - Very easy! Ordered 1. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet 2. Consectetur adipiscing elit 3. Integer molestie lorem at massa 4. You can use sequential numbers... 5. ...or keep all the numbers as `1.` Start numbering with offset: 57. foo 1. bar ## Code Inline `code` Block code ``` Sample text here... ``` Syntax highlighting ```js var foo = function (bar) { return bar++; }; console.log(foo(5)); ``` Syntax highlighting with file name, highlight line ```ts:cores.ts {2} export const cn = (classNames: ...any) => { return classNames.filter(Boolean).join(' '); } ``` ## Tables | Option | Description | | ------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | data | path to data files to supply the data that will be passed into templates. | | engine | engine to be used for processing templates.
